Title: Prove $\gcd(a+b, a-b) = 1$ or $2\,$ if $\,\gcd(a,b) = 1$
Content: I want to show that for $\gcd(a,b) = 1$ $a,b \in Z$   $\gcd(a+b, a-b) = 1$ or $\gcd(a+b, a-b) = 2$ holds. I think the first step should look something like this: $d = \gcd(a+b, a-b) = \gcd(2a, a-b)$ From here I tried to proceed with two cases. 1: $a-b$ is even, which leads to $\gcd(a+b, a-b) = 2$ 2: $a-b$ is odd, which leads to $\gcd(a+b, a-b) = 1$ My main problem I think is, that I do not know how I should include $\gcd(a,b) = 1$ in the proof. Any help is appreciated. Thx in advance. Cherio Woltan
AcceptedAnswer: Let $d$ be a common divisor of $a+b$ and $a-b$ , then $d$ divides their sum $2a$ and difference $2b$ . If a number divides two numbers it also divides their gcd, thus $d$ divides $2\gcd(a,b) = 2$ . That implies that every divisor (including the greatest common divisor) is a divisor of $2$ . The same argument again in symbols: Let $d \mid a+b, a-b$ , then $d \mid (a+b)+(a-b) = 2a$ and $d \mid (a+b)-(a-b) = 2b$ so $d \mid \gcd(2a,2b) = 2$ .
